message:
For the network geeks out there, I get internet in my house via some mysterious wireless device on my roof that connects to an internet provider about 3 Kms away.

Anyway, those people are seriously incompetent, and I never run out of internet problems on a daily basis. The latest issues is randomly getting 404 errors. The issue is completely random, not related to a certain site or a certain time.

I tried changing my DNS server to 8.8.8.8 to no effect. The issue only goes away when I use an SSH tunnel to a USA server, which of course is too slow for daily usage.

I appreciate any help on this matter, since my incompetent ISP do not even know where to start looking.

data.message: I had a similar issue with a TEDATA connection with some parameter that needed adjustment , it was about maximum frame size or something like this (layer 2 parameter) it should be 66 or something like that , I changed my modem and didnt have the sameissue later so I can't remember the exact names and values

Was that "MTU Size"?

It was set to a default value of 1500, a bit of online research showed that LinkDSL (which is the provider behind my ISP) uses a value of 1492. I tried that and will see what happens.
Nope, the same stupid issue is still there.
Yes exactly , i will try to find the value i needed
I remember that when using vpn , i was ok
As I thought, seems that someone is caching things locally, this 404 looks ancient, this is what stack overflow 404 looks like:
The 404 page I am getting looks suspiciously like IIS 6 or something of that era.
Now this is funny, I changed the MTU again as per Mohamed's suggestion, now I am getting this (this domain is owned by LinkDSL)  :D
Your isp is providing caching service for u ?
Apparently someone thought of coming up with something 'clever' and started this whole mess.
would u face same issue when using tor ? I would assume the answer is no , also do you face it with http only ?
I believe it won't show up with TOR. As for the protocol, it does not matter whether it is http or https.
This looks very much like a crappy caching system
